author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: E.U. Agrees to Slash Carbon Emissions by 2030
description: The agreement calls for European Union countries to cut their collective greenhouse gas emissions by 55 percent from 1990 levels, a more substantial reduction than previously proposed.
content: BRUSSELS — After an all-night negotiating session, European Union leaders agreed on Friday morning to cut net carbon emissions by 55 percent in the next decade from levels measured in 1990, overcoming the concerns of nations still heavily dependent on coal and taking a critical step in the effort to become climate-neutral by 2050.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Tone Is Hard to Grasp Online. Can Tone Indicators Help?’
description: In this lesson, students will explore the challenges of communication in the age of the internet — and what we can do to make it better.
content: Featured Article: “Tone Is Hard to Grasp Online. Can Tone Indicators Help?” by Ezra Marcus with videos by Shane O’Neill
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Vire
title: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Happy Endings’
description: In its day, this hangout comedy was lumped in with “Friends.” But its crisp, rat-a-tat style is more like “30 Rock.”
content: In a second-season episode of “Happy Endings,” the much-loved but little-watched comedy that ran on ABC from 2011 to 2013, the show acknowledged a comparison that had been dogging it since its premiere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Pfizer Vaccine, N.Y.C. Dining, Dionne Warwick: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Biden Clashes With the Left
description: Democrats are trying to work out their differences as Biden prepares to take office. It’s Friday, and this is your politics tip sheet.
content: Democrats are trying to work out their differences as Biden prepares to take office. But across party lines, a lot feels unbridgeable. It’s Friday, and this is your politics tip sheet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr and Sean Piccoli
title: Piano Bars and Jazz Clubs Reopened, Calling Live Music ‘Incidental’
description: Before Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo moved to ban indoor dining again in New York City, several music clubs had begun offering performances again that they claimed were background music.
content: Although most indoor live performances have been banned in New York since the coronavirus began its deadly spread in March, about a dozen people turned up Wednesday night at Birdland, the jazz club near Times Square, for a 7 p.m. performance that was billed as dinner with live jazz. They had reservations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Biden and Harris Are Time’s Persons of the Year for 2020
description: The magazine chose the president-elect and the vice president-elect over frontline health care workers (along with Dr. Anthony S. Fauci), the racial justice movement and President Trump.
content: Time magazine on Thursday named President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris as its persons of the year, citing the weight of the pandemic and racial injustice that will be shouldered by the history-making Democratic ticket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Jeremy W. Peters
title: In Blistering Retort, 4 Battleground States Tell Texas to Butt Out of Election
description: The attorneys general of Pennsylvania, Michigan, Wisconsin and Georgia asked the Supreme Court to reject a lawsuit from Texas seeking to overturn President-elect Joe Biden’s victories.
content: WASHINGTON — In blistering language denouncing Republican efforts to subvert the election, the attorneys general for Pennsylvania, Michigan, Wisconsin and Georgia asked the Supreme Court on Thursday to reject a lawsuit that seeks to overturn the victories in those states by President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., calling the audacious effort an affront to democracy and the rule of law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Cole
title: Hawaii’s Next Wave of Natural Skin-Care Brands
description: A new generation of beauty companies is rediscovering the islands’ powerful native ingredients, from taro to ferns.
content: It is not altogether surprising that Hawaii is at the forefront of our current golden age of natural skin care, in which botanical face oils and mushroom-infused elixirs abound. Few places on Earth contain such a diversity of plant species, and Hawaiians have been using this bounty — including nutrient-rich varieties such as hibiscus, coconut, ferns and kukui nuts — as a source of nourishment and healing for generations. Indeed, plants have been prized on the islands since the first millennium A.D., when the ancient Polynesians arrived by canoe, bringing with them life-sustaining crops such as taro, breadfruit and sweet potato. And though centuries of colonization have done their best to erode this deep-rooted connection to the natural world, it has endured. In fact, for many of the founders of the latest wave of Hawaii-based skin-care lines, using locally sourced botanical ingredients is simply common sense, part of a reciprocal, age-old relationship between the islands and their inhabitants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Bryn Terfel Returns to the Metropolitan Opera. (Sort Of.)
description: A holiday recital, streamed live from Wales, will be this star singer’s first headlining performance for the Met since 2012.
content: The airy studio where Bryn Terfel practices is set a good few yards from the house in Penarth, Wales, that he shares with his wife and two young children. Given his thunderous bass-baritone voice, which has roared through the great roles of Mozart, Puccini, Verdi and Wagner at opera houses around the world over the past 30 years, this is probably essential to family sanity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: They Had Given Up on Love
description: Luke Rivett and Sunney Kohlhoss met at a Los Angeles bar last year. “We talked for a few minutes,” he said. “I told her, ‘I’m going to marry you.’”
content: When Luke Rivett spotted Sunney Kohlhoss on March 1, 2019 at the Well, a bar in Los Angeles, both had recently given up on love, resolving halfheartedly, that they would be single forever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Stimulus Deal Falters as McConnell Signals Republican Resistance
description: Aides to the senate majority leader privately warned that most Republicans would be unlikely to support an emerging compromise on liability protections and state and local funding.
content: WASHINGTON — Efforts to reach a year-end agreement on a stimulus package to prop up the shuddering economy faltered on Thursday as aides to Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, signaled privately that most Republicans were unlikely to endorse an emerging bipartisan compromise without changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: He Had Her at Sourdough
description: Plus: When digital dates fizzle in real life.
content: Many extroverts have gone to extreme measures for a social fix during the pandemic. Albertina Coacci, a self-proclaimed people person, turned to daily phone calls with strangers to pass the time while in lockdown in Italy. What started as a harmless habit soon led to an affair of sorts with a man who spoke her love language: baking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Neil MacFarquhar
title: After more than 3,000 U.S. deaths in a day, a warning: ‘The worst is yet to come.’
description: The new daily record of coronavirus deaths is a stunning number in and of itself.
content: The new daily record of coronavirus deaths is a stunning number in and of itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Delfino
title: The Wild Ways Parents Preserve Their Kids’ Memories
description: There’s nothing wrong with collecting belly buttons, teeth and locks of hair. It’s just part of the process.
content: The large, wooden box on the floor of my mom’s bedroom reminded me of a pirate’s treasure chest. We were never allowed to open it ourselves, but every so often, my mother would sit my sisters and me down to share the booty within: locks of our hair, worn photographs of us sitting on Santa’s lap, pictures we drew that she couldn’t bear to part with, a ceramic pig I made in grade school. Her face would soften as she would recount the details of each piece.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Airbnb’s Stunning I.P.O.
description: The home-rental company’s stock debut briefly left its own chief speechless.
content: Brian Chesky, Airbnb’s co-founder and C.E.O., was left momentarily speechless on live television yesterday after being told his company’s shares were set to begin trading at $139, after its I.P.O. had priced them at $68. (They eventually closed at $144.71.) He may as well have been speaking for Wall Street and Silicon Valley, which were left agog by a frenzy for tech I.P.O.s this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: A State Scientist Questioned Florida’s Virus Data. Now Her Home’s Been Raided.
description: Rebekah Jones became an unlikely celebrity when she lost her job running the state’s coronavirus data dashboard. Police say a breach at the Department of Health was traced to her computer.
content: MIAMI — The complicated story of how a Florida data scientist responsible for managing the state’s coronavirus numbers wound up with state police agents brandishing guns in her house this week began seven long months ago, when the scientist, Rebekah D. Jones, was removed from her post at the Florida Department of Health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Miriam Jordan
title: The Vaccines Are Coming. A Divided and Distrustful America Awaits.
description: A vast majority of people will need to be vaccinated to create a decisive decline in infections. Health officials are scrambling to make that happen.
content: As the Lopez family of Truckee, Calif., gathered to prepare dinner on a recent evening, one subject dominated the conversation: the coronavirus vaccine that will soon be shipped out across the country, giving Americans the first concrete hope that the pandemic will eventually end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Zoom Classes. No Chance Meetings. Is Virtual Business School Worth the Cost?
description: Students in the M.B.A. class of 2021 have been hit particularly hard. The degree can cost $200,000, not counting lost wages.
content: Getting a master’s in business administration is about a lot more than book learning.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The 46th’: Who Will Replace Trump in the G.O.P.’s Heart?
description: Jane Coaston and Sean Trende join Ross to debate whether Republicans will remain the party of Trumpism, post-Trump.
content: Listen and subscribe to “The Argument” from your mobile device:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Rosa
title: The Threat Against New York’s Bodegas
description: Bodegas, often seen as safe havens, have been hit by a crime wave during the pandemic.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: Diamonds and Campaign Trails in Houston
description: Erin Mincberg and Scotty Spiegel grew up only five blocks apart, but didn’t connect until decades later when he asked for some career advice about the political world.
content: The Westbury Little League is a sprawling collection of baseball diamonds lumped together like Cracker Jacks in Houston. The fields there vary in size to accommodate players at different stages of youth. If you’d walked onto one of the larger fields on a Saturday in the early 1990s, you would likely have found a 12-year-old Scotty Spiegel leaping up to the plate, happily sweating in the Texas sun. If you’d then strolled over to one of the smaller diamonds, you might have seen the opposite image: Erin Mincberg, age 9, somber in her uniform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Turner
title: ‘Safety’ Review: It Takes a University to Raise a Child
description: This Disney+ film isn’t your typical sports or adversity movie; it asks questions of what educational institutions owe to their community.
content: They say it takes a village to raise a child, but in “Safety,” it takes an entire university campus to do so. Overly sentimental traps line the plot of the film, streaming on Disney+. But it scores points for giving its lead characters complicated situations, emotional depth and political dimension.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Dorian Electra, a Queer Pop Star Who Defies Genres
description: The singer recently released music that tangles together metal, dubstep and hard-core punk, “all these hypermasculine, testosterone-filled genres.”
content: Name: Dorian Electra
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: The Pandemic’s Toll on College Football
description: A Times analysis uncovered a sobering number of coronavirus cases in college athletic departments.
content: This year’s college football season got off to a rocky start as parents protested attempts to cancel the season and President Trump waded into the debate. And it has taken some major hits, with high-profile coaches and players testing positive for the coronavirus and team outbreaks interrupting marquee games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Ben Protess and David Enrich
title: Manhattan D.A. Intensifies Investigation of Trump
description: Prosecutors have recently interviewed employees of President Trump’s lender and insurance brokerage, in the latest indication that he still faces the potential threat of criminal charges once he leaves office.
content: State prosecutors in Manhattan have interviewed several employees of President Trump’s bank and insurance broker in recent weeks, according to people with knowledge of the matter, significantly escalating an investigation into the president that he is powerless to stop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder, Lauryn Higgins and Benjamin Guggenheim
title: College Sports Has Reported at Least 6,629 Virus Cases. There Are Many More.
description: The N.C.A.A. does not track coronavirus cases, but a New York Times analysis shows the pandemic’s toll across college athletics. Many universities have kept their case counts from the public.
content: More than 6,600 college athletes, coaches and staff members have tested positive for the coronavirus this year, a dispiriting measure of the pathogen’s reach across the United States and its spread among some of the country’s most closely monitored people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: It’s Not Just You: Picking a Health Insurance Plan Is Really Hard
description: Most Americans make poor choices. So do most professional insurance brokers, a new study finds. But robots may help.
content: Anya Samek, an economist, has found that consumers make better choices among health plans when presented with a few simple calculations. So when she switched jobs last year and had to choose a plan herself, she tried entering the various plan features into a spreadsheet to replicate her tool. She gave up, determining the task too complicated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: How We Passed the Time this Year
description: Making sense of the year in culture.
content: Welcome. My colleagues are looking back at the ways culture was upended in 2020, and their reflections are helping me make sense of a year that frequently seemed senseless. James Poniewozik put it best, I think, pointing out that this is the year “everything became TV”: We watched “I May Destroy You” on Netflix, and used the same screen to attend school, to take yoga classes, to commune over Thanksgiving dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jo Nesbo Talks About ‘The Kingdom’
description: Nesbo discusses his latest novel, and David Michaelis talks about his new biography of Eleanor Roosevelt.
content: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: A Single Senator Dashes Hopes for Latino and Women’s Museums — For Now
description: Senator Mike Lee, Republican of Utah, blocked the creation of Smithsonian museums honoring women and Latinos, warning they would worsen societal divides.
content: For more than two decades, Latinos and their allies in Congress have been fighting to approve the creation of a National Museum of the American Latino in Washington. The push to create a national women’s history museum has taken about as long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Roast a Chicken
description: Mark Bittman’s simple recipe can yield days of soul-sustaining dinners.
content: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. On Tuesday, I roasted a chicken for dinner, which I don’t do nearly enough. It’s typically faster to cook chicken breasts, thighs or legs instead, and easier to serve them too (no carving). Those little advantages spell big impact when everyone is hungry and cranky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: ‘Evermore,’ Taylor Swift’s ‘Folklore’ Sequel, Is a Journey Deeper Inward
description: The singer and songwriter’s July album traded glossy sheen for an acoustic-Minimalistic palette. A second album with the same collaborators moves even further from her pop past.
content: Sequels are always tricky. The original is a creative leap; the follow-up is likely to be incremental. Until now, Taylor Swift has switched up her collaborators and general sound with each album. But she has rightly billed “Evermore,” her surprise-release ninth album, as the “sister” to the one she released less than five months ago, “Folklore.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Emily Cochrane
title: A Top House Democrat Prods Biden to Reopen E.U. Trade Talks
description: The chairman of the powerful Ways and Means Committee countered the president-elect’s pledge to focus first on domestic priorities.
content: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the powerful House Ways and Means Committee urged the incoming administration to renew trade negotiations with the European Union, countering a pledge by President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. to postpone any new trade talks until after the United States has made significant domestic investments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Snow Leopards Are the Latest Cats to Be Infected With the Coronavirus
description: Lions and tigers had already contracted the virus, but have recovered.
content: Snow leopards at the Louisville Zoo are the latest animals to be infected with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Lisa Friedman
title: For Biden’s Economic Team, an Early Focus on Climate
description: In announcing key economic advisers in the White House and the cabinet, the president-elect has emphasized action to boost clean energy and reduce emissions
content: WASHINGTON — The video rollouts of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s pick for Treasury secretary, Janet L. Yellen, and National Economic Council director, Brian Deese, began biographically. But they quickly shifted to focus on an issue that could distinguish Mr. Biden’s core economic team from its predecessors: climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and John Branch
title: Climate Change and California’s Favorite Trees
description: Friday: How wildfires could threaten the coast redwood, the Joshua tree and the giant sequoia. Also: What to know about California’s contact tracing app.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: Norman Abramson, Pioneer Behind Wireless Networks, Dies at 88
description: His ALOHAnet, designed a half-century ago in Hawaii, was a precursor to the technology used in today’s smartphones and home WiFi networks.
content: Norman Abramson, the leader of a group of scientists and engineers who pioneered the development of wireless computer networks, died on Dec. 1 at his home in San Francisco. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: A Cart Crash, a Pain Pill and a Shot at the Lead
description: Cristie Kerr was afraid she might not be able to play in the U.S. Women’s Open after an accident that injured her and her caddie last week. Playing in pain, she’s five shots off the lead.
content: HOUSTON — The U.S. Women’s Open is one of Cristie Kerr’s favorite things, the tournament that she most wants to win every year. But in her zeal to add a trophy to bookend her 2007 title in the event, she has often hurt herself by overthinking her strategy, overdoing her preparation, overemphasizing the results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Prominent Architects Group Prohibits Design of Death Chambers
description: The American Institute of Architects has changed its stance on members who design spaces for executions or prolonged solitary confinement.
content: The American Institute of Architects said Friday that it had approved new ethics rules prohibiting members from knowingly designing spaces intended for execution or torture, including for prolonged periods of solitary confinement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Miller
title: Female Workers Could Take Another Pandemic Hit: To Their Retirements
description: Unequal job losses now will translate into smaller nest eggs and Social Security benefits down the road.
content: During the first months of the pandemic, Leah Tyrrell found that she could pull off a balancing act: working in sales for a San Diego clothing maker and caring for her three young daughters at home. Her hours had been reduced, and working remotely in the morning left her time to be with the children the rest of the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady
title: Pfizer’s Covid Vaccine and Allergies: How Concerned Should You Be?
description: British health officials recommended that people with severe allergy reactions not be given the vaccine. Such reactions to vaccines are rare, even in people who have allergies to food or bee stings.
content: The decision by British drug regulators to recommend against use of the coronavirus vaccine made by Pfizer and BioNTech in people who have a history of severe allergic reactions has raised a number of concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Australia Scraps Covid-19 Vaccine That Produced H.I.V. False Positives
description: Of the dozens of coronavirus vaccines being tested worldwide, the one under development at the University of Queensland was the first to be abandoned.
content: Australia on Friday canceled a roughly $750 million plan for a large order of a locally developed coronavirus vaccine after the inoculation produced false positive test results for H.I.V. in some volunteers participating in a trial study.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: The Third Proposal Stuck
description: Carl Mumford Jr. and Antia Adam, who met at Savannah State University, broke up shortly after the first two times he proposed. He didn’t give up.
content: Antia Adams couldn’t blame Carl Mumford Jr. for issuing a warning with his February 2019 marriage proposal. “He said, ‘If you lose this one, that’s it,’” Ms. Adams said. Mr. Mumford had already given her two engagement rings. She lost both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Fallon: Trump’s Hanukkah Party Was a ‘Festival of Lies’
description: “Even the dreidel was looking at Trump like, ‘Damn, this guy spins more than I do,’” Fallon joked on Wednesday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian Friedman
title: Jobless Benefits Saved Them, Until States Wanted the Money Back
description: A pandemic relief program allows no forgiveness of overpayments, even when recipients are not at fault and the funds are already spent.
content: Unemployment payments that looked like a lifeline may now, for many, become their ruin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Rep. Max Rose Moves Toward Entering New York City Mayor’s Race
description: The Staten Island Democrat, coming off a re-election loss, filed paperwork indicating that he is set to enter an already crowded field.
content: Representative Max Rose, the Staten Island Democrat who was soundly defeated last month in his bid for a second term, signaled on Thursday that he plans to enter an already crowded field in the 2021 mayor’s race in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: How Neighbors Are Coming Together to Buy Local for the Holidays
description: “I’m not buying anything from freaking Jeff Bezos,” says a member of a Red Hook business group.
content: Some New Yorkers, in an effort to support entrepreneurs instead of large corporations, are creating hyperlocal shopping experiences this holiday season. Facebook groups, Instagram accounts and neighborhood holiday markets — think of them as micro-Etsy projects, organized via social media — have cropped up to showcase local talents and businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Chris Buckley
title: Jimmy Lai, Media Mogul, Is Charged Under Hong Kong’s Security Law
description: Mr. Lai’s case was followed hours later by a disclosure that the authorities in China had detained a Chinese citizen working for Bloomberg News.
content: HONG KONG — In two strokes unveiled on Friday, the Chinese Communist Party laid out in stark relief the rapidly shrinking space for speech and independent journalism in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Gwen Stefani’s Ska-Pop Flashback, and 10 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Sturgill Simpson, John Carpenter, Elle King and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: At the U.S. Women’s Open, a Love Story
description: They met playing against each other in rec league hockey. Now Alena Sharp and her caddie, Sarah Bowman, are honeymooning on the golf course.
content: HOUSTON — The honeymoon began, as so many do for golf-obsessed newlyweds, with 18 holes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Covid Meds Are Scarce, but Not for Trump Cronies
description: Rudy Giuliani got monoclonal antibodies. You probably can’t.
content: According to a document from the Department of Health and Human Services, a total of 108 doses of Regeneron’s monoclonal antibody cocktail have been allocated to Washington, which had 265 new coronavirus cases on Wednesday alone. Somehow Rudy Giuliani, Donald Trump’s lawyer, got one of those doses. In an interview with a New York radio station on Tuesday, Giuliani did us all the favor of explaining why he qualified for privileged treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Co-ops in the Time of Covid
description: New York’s enduring vertical village, the cooperative, has faced a variety of challenges during the pandemic.
content: Of the hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers who left the city in the early months of the pandemic, there are a few that Lori Levine van Arsdale won’t miss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Neil MacFarquhar
title: ‘Numb’ and ‘Heartbroken,’ the U.S. Confronts Record Virus Deaths
description: For the first time, the United States reported more than 3,000 coronavirus deaths in a day. But with cases still rising, experts warn “the worst is yet to come.”
content: DALLAS — Lillian Blancas was a fighter, a proud daughter of immigrants, part of the first generation in her family to attend college and a lawyer in El Paso who was on the brink of fulfilling her dream of becoming a judge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: Justice Department Executes Man for Murder Committed When He Was 18
description: Despite a high-profile clemency campaign by allies of President Trump, the administration executed Brandon Bernard by lethal injection for his role in the 1999 crime.
content: WASHINGTON — Despite a high-profile clemency campaign, the Justice Department executed Brandon Bernard by lethal injection on Thursday for his part in a 1999 double murder-robbery when he was 18.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: With the Virus Surging, Arizona Teachers Protest by Calling In Sick
description: The sickout in Chandler, Ariz., reflects growing discord over whether classrooms should remain open as virus cases spike.
content: In a reflection of debates nationwide over whether to keep classrooms open during the current surge in coronavirus cases, about 100 teachers in Arizona’s third-largest school district staged a sickout on Friday, demanding that schools close after winter break and stay remote until the region’s infection rate declines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: They Ended Up Believing in Marriage (and Santa Delivered)
description: Michele Pascuzzi and Brian Nowicki were reluctant to marry again. But they found some magic with each other.
content: Michele Pascuzzi and Brian Nowicki were adamant about not dating. Both had been married before — Ms. Pascuzzi was married twice and Mr. Nowicki once. Ms. Pascuzzi had a son; and Mr. Nowicki had a son with his first wife and two stepchildren. When their mutual friends offered to introduce them, each refused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Marking a Missed Wedding Date With a Bouquet
description: Karan Ganjawalla and Juhi Kuchroo were married in a quiet ceremony on Thanksgiving after canceling a multiday Indian wedding planned for last May.
content: Dr. Karan Ganjawalla, a 32-year-old maxillofacial surgery resident at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, ditched his scrubs for biking gear on May 23 and made a special house call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: scud
description: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Bonus: Kara Swisher and Ben Smith Debrief on Jason Kilar
description: It potentially involves a head on a platter.
content: This week, Kara Swisher interviewed WarnerMedia’s chief executive, Jason Kilar, fresh on the heels of the announcement that Warner Bros. will release its 2021 film slate in theaters and on its streaming site, HBO Max, simultaneously. (If you missed that episode — scroll back and hit play! Or click here if you’re on the World Wide Web).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman, Katie Benner and Ben Protess
title: Material From Giuliani Spurred a Separate Justice Dept. Pursuit of Hunter Biden
description: The inquiry, based out of Pittsburgh, was run parallel to an investigation in Delaware and raised alarms among F.B.I. agents about politicization.
content: WASHINGTON — As federal investigators in Delaware were examining the finances of Hunter Biden during his father’s campaign for president, a similar inquiry ramped up this year in Pittsburgh, fueled by materials delivered by President Trump’s personal lawyer Rudolph W. Giuliani.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Holiday Flicks
description: What are your favorite (or not-so-favorite) holiday films?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Businessman Pays Overdue Utility Bills for Dozens of Floridians, Again
description: Mike Esmond knew what it was like to be broke and get his heat cut off in a brutal winter. So, for the second year in a row, he paid residents’ overdue utility bills in Gulf Breeze, Fla.
content: Mike Esmond walked into City Hall in Gulf Breeze, Fla., in November 2019 and cut a check for $4,300 to pay for 36 local residents whose gas and water bills were overdue and at risk of being disconnected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Texas replies to 4 states in its lawsuit to overturn their election results.
description: The justices of the Supreme Court met Friday morning, by telephone, for their usual private conference to discuss which cases they might add to their docket.
content: The justices of the Supreme Court met Friday morning, by telephone, for their usual private conference to discuss which cases they might add to their docket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Trump Tries to Kill Covid Relief
description: Is it ignorance, or is it cynicism?
content: The next few months will be terrible. Several thousand Americans are now dying from Covid-19 every day; given the lag between cases and deaths, the daily toll will almost certainly rise through the end of this year, and if people are careless over Christmas it could surge even higher in the new year. Economic recovery has stalled, with employment still down almost 10 million from pre-pandemic levels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: How to Rediscover the Art of Bipartisan Deal Making
description: A group of experts gathered to debate the prospects for compromise in an era of partisanship.
content: Months of negotiations and competing pandemic relief proposals have not yet yielded a deal, prompting lawmakers in Washington recently to extend the deadline for talks. A $908 billion package born from compromise, proposed by a group in the House and the Senate who staked a middle ground between Democrats’ proposed $2 trillion and Republicans’ $500 billion “skinny” bill, is at the center of discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: How to Handle Bad Co-Workers of the Anti-Mask and Boyfriend Varieties
description: It isn’t all about you. Or your officemate (even if you are living with him).
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Indoor Dining Will Shut Down in New York City Again
description: The decision, intended to slow a second wave of coronavirus cases, is a blow to the struggling restaurant industry.
content: Indoor dining will once again be barred in New York City restaurants starting on Monday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Friday, in a significant reversal of the city’s reopening that comes as officials try to halt the escalation of a second wave of the coronavirus and avoid a broader shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: How to Make a Spectacular Holiday Trifle
description: Flamboyant, fruity and exceedingly merry, trifles are a show-off dessert with a self-effacing name.
content: Of all the British puddings with their whimsical names — the roly-poly, the spotted dick, the whim wham and the Eton mess — none is as popular on this side of the pond as a custardy, boozy, cream-topped trifle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Brittanya Karma, German-Vietnamese Social Media Star, Dies at 29
description: She used her social media clout to preach and model self-confidence. She died of complications of Covid-19 in a Hamburg hospital.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass
title: Who James Baldwin Knew
description: The celebrated writer moved between many worlds, becoming close friends with major figures — from Marlon Brando to Toni Morrison — in art, activism and beyond.
content: This story is part of T’s Book Club, a series of articles and events dedicated to classic works of American literature. Click here to R.S.V.P. to a virtual conversation, led by Ayana Mathis, about “Go Tell It on the Mountain” on Dec. 17.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Take Turns, Say
description: Find a friend or two to tackle Ari Richter’s Friday puzzle (here we are!).
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This is Ari Richter’s second Times puzzle (the first was last spring, a Saturday grid), and it’s another excellent themeless challenge with a bunch of good debuts. It also holds a neat surprise, if you like this sort of detail, which is that it’s a pangram — every letter in the alphabet appears at least once in the entries. It’s only the third one this year, and I always imagine a constructor pulling a string here or there to get that “J” or “X” in with as little clunkiness as possible. In this case, mission definitely accomplished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: A Traditional, but Unexpected, Christmas Showstopper
description: Yotam Ottolenghi usually leaves the Christmas meals to his husband. But dessert is where he shines, making this riff on the classic bûche de Noël.
content: I grew up largely unaware of Christmas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Giannis Antetokounmpo Has Plenty of Pens. But Will He Sign?
description: The Milwaukee Bucks superstar was gifted pens by many of his teammates in hopes he would sign a so-called supermax deal with the team. In a complicated business, it’s not that simple.
content: When the Milwaukee Bucks showed up for training camp on Sunday, Khris Middleton presented his teammate Giannis Antetokounmpo with a gift for his 26th birthday: a pen. Antetokounmpo did not understand its significance at first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘The Bee Gees’ Review: Night Fever, for Decades
description: The documentary “How Can You Mend a Broken Heart,” from Frank Marshall, strives to paint a wider picture of the band often associated with its disco hits.
content: “The Bee Gees: How Can You Mend a Broken Heart” pays tribute to the Gibb brothers with a tour of their pop music reign. Grooving through the decades, this entertaining documentary aspires to prove that the Bee Gees were more than a hitmaker for disco nightclubs. Rather, Barry, Maurice and Robin were master songwriters and chameleons, continually reinventing themselves to harmonize with the times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters, David Montgomery, Linda Qiu and Adam Liptak
title: Two reasons the Texas election case is faulty: flawed legal theory and statistical fallacy.
description: Texas has asked the Supreme Court to reverse the election results, but the case’s legal argument is flawed and its statistical assertion that Joe Biden had a minuscule chance to win is “comical,” experts said.
content: Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, has asked the Supreme Court to do something it has never done before: disenfranchise millions of voters in four states and reverse the results of the presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lia Picard
title: Everyone Gather Round the Squirrel Table. (Chipmunks Too!)
description: Enticing wildlife to the backyard, with tiny furniture and elaborate meals, has consoled some Americans in quarantine.
content: Thelonious Munk sits down for an alfresco meal at a wooden table. He eagerly picks up a taco prepared with a walnut flour tortilla, which he sniffs before taking a few nibbles. He lingers for a bit after his meal before leaving. He scampers into a bush and through a tunnel — because he isn’t checking out the latest vegan restaurant, but is instead a wild chipmunk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grant Snider
title: Dreaming About the Ideal Library
description: If your fantasies turn toward curling up with a book or perusing endless miles of shelves, we have some food for your imagination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Lisa Lerer
title: Brian Kemp Cast His Lot With Trump, and Has Now Paid the Price
description: Mr. Kemp rose to Georgia’s governorship with the help of President Trump, but his refusal to try to overturn the state’s election results has drawn Mr. Trump’s ire — and may affect his political future.
content: ATLANTA — Few politicians have been both elevated and diminished by the vicissitudes of President Trump like Brian Kemp, the Republican governor of Georgia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Behind the Cover: Great Performers
description: A look at the best screen actors of 2020
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Biden Names Two Obama White House Veterans to New Roles
description: Susan Rice, who was President Barack Obama’s national security adviser, will lead the Domestic Policy Council. Denis McDonough, Mr. Obama’s chief of staff, was nominated secretary of veterans affairs.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. named two senior officials from the Obama White House to key jobs on Thursday, putting Susan Rice, a former national security adviser, in charge of his Domestic Policy Council and nominating President Barack Obama’s chief of staff, Denis McDonough, to be secretary of veterans affairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: An Impressive Centerpiece in Just Five Ingredients
description: The year has been difficult. Your holiday dinner — a gorgeous slab of salmon cooked beneath a simple glaze — doesn’t have to be.
content: Savory-sweet fish, topped with tangles of herbs and bright lemon juice, looks and tastes like a celebration for your pandemic pod. There’s an unexpected inverse relationship between how easy it is to make this dish and how special it feels when it’s served. A four-ingredient, five-minute glaze coats a single slab of salmon, and the whole thing comes together in under 30 minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: In Sickness and in Health, They Stayed in Sync
description: Jessica Vande Werken and Robin Goode supported each other when Ms. Goode received a breast cancer diagnosis. Almost a year later, they unknowingly made appointments to pick out engagement rings at the same shop, on the same day.
content: In July 2018, Jessica Vande Werken was nervously waiting for her date, Robin Imogene Goode, at Cubbyhole, a bar in Manhattan. They had matched on Tinder, and were meeting in person for the first time. When Ms. Goode walked into the bar, Ms. Vande Werken noticed her immediately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Hezbollah Member Sentenced in Absentia Over Killing of Ex-Premier in Lebanon
description: A United Nations-backed tribunal in The Hague handed down the symbolic life sentence in connection with the 2005 assassination of Rafik Hariri.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A United Nations-backed tribunal in The Hague on Friday sentenced a member of the Hezbollah militant group to life in prison after convicting him in absentia of conspiring in the 2005 car-bomb attack that killed former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri of Lebanon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘The Mandalorian’ Season 2, Episode 7 Recap: Face-off on Morak
description: Mando joins forces with an old enemy, just one of several major compromises he makes in hopes of rescuing Grogu.
content: It was bound to happen. All season long, Mando has been suffering loss after loss. The Child’s floating transport-egg? Totaled. The Razor Crest? Destroyed. Grogu himself? Kidnapped. So it was inevitable that at some point, Mando was going to have to give up what has mattered to him more than anything for most of his life: his helmet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: New Star of ‘The Prom’ Sees a Chance to Make L.G.B.T.Q. Characters Visible
description: Like her character, Jo Ellen Pellman identifies as queer, and she is making her film debut in the Netflix musical alongside A-listers like Meryl Streep and Nicole Kidman.
content: During her second day ever on a film set, Jo Ellen Pellman came face to face with an irate Meryl Streep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: What Role Does Religion Play in Your Life?
description: How would you describe your spiritual beliefs? Can you pick and choose which aspects of religion to follow?
content: Note: One of the questions in this forum was suggested by Katarina, a student. She asks: “Can you pick and choose which aspects of religion to follow?” If you have an idea for a question inspired by a New York Times article that we should ask in our Student Opinion column, you can submit it here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Dyett
title: The Bittersweet Tale of a Diner, a Toy Shop and a Changing New York
description: One is expanding. One is closing. But not all is lost.
content: Over time, certain city blocks become niche shopping and dining hubs, destinations that are quintessentially New York, marked by local history and personalities, while defining the broader neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Altman
title: It’s In-Law Season. Here’s How to Get Along.
description: In-laws are often thrust into life’s most intimate moments without much agreement on how things should be handled. It can make these relationships … complicated.
content: — Geoffrey Greif, a co-author of “In-Law Relationships: Mothers, Daughters, Fathers, and Sons.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Give Virus Alert Apps a Shot
description: These Google and Apple apps work and aren’t stealing all your data. More people should use them.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: ‘Giving Voice’ Review: August Wilson Is Uplifting a New Generation
description: Netflix’s inspirational documentary follows talented theater kids who are devoting themselves to Wilson’s writing.
content: The everyday hopes and heartbreaks of African-Americans were dramatized in August Wilson’s 10-play Century Cycle. And every year, since Wilson’s death in 2005, thousands of students from 12 different cities vie for the chance to perform a monologue from one of his plays in a competition’s final round on Broadway. James D. Stern and Fernando Villena’s uplifting documentary “Giving Voice” (streaming on Netflix) further explores this competition and explains how the playwright’s legacy is inspiring a new generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gayle Abrams
title: Saving a Cactus, and Its Prickly Owner
description: I didn’t think I’d ever get over the loss of my best friend. Then her daughter came to live with me.
content: “Will you accept a new tenant and a puppy?” Ceece texted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman
title: Israel-Morocco Deal Follows History of Cooperation on Arms and Spying
description: For almost 60 years, the two countries, which agreed to normalize ties, have worked together closely but secretly on military and intelligence matters, assassinations, and migration of Jews to Israel.
content: Behind the announcement Thursday that Israel and Morocco will establish their first formal diplomatic ties, there lies almost six decades of close, secret cooperation on intelligence and military matters between two nations that officially did not acknowledge each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Albertina Coacci
title: He Seduced Me With Bread
description: An Italian woman, trapped in lockdown, takes daily calls from strangers until she finds one who really knows how to cook.
content: Years ago, with a friend, I played one of those psychological games where you begin by listing 15 things you would bring to a desert island and then narrow the list until you’re down to the two most important. By painfully dismissing one cherished item after another, I was left with my final choices: a guitar and “the people I don’t yet know.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: The New Influencer Capital of America
description: After years of being passed over by brands and management companies despite driving the internet’s biggest trends, Black influencers in Atlanta are working to shift the paradigm.
content: ATLANTA — It’s no secret Atlanta is one of the nation’s great culture capitals, home to many power brokers in music, fashion and the arts — a city that, since the 1980s, has produced some of the biggest names in rap, R&B and hip-hop, and over the last decade, seen explosive growth in its entertainment industry (thanks, in part, to Georgia’s generous tax credits).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Winning in the Contest of Love
description: Jennifer McClay and Steve Gustafson, who met at Duke University Hospital, won a free wedding package after a friend entered a contest on their behalf.
content: When Jennifer McClay read the letter her friend Hannah Bentley sent to Cates Farm, a Hillsborough, N.C., events space that was holding a contest for essential workers hoping to win a free wedding package, she cried.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Their Team Almost Left Town. Now It’s Playing for a Title.
description: Fan activism, public pressure and new owners kept the Columbus Crew in Ohio. On Saturday, the team will try to pay back its supporters by winning M.L.S. Cup on its home field.
content: The Columbus Crew is not supposed to be here right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: That New York Vibe and a Life in San Diego
description: Ana Bowens and Benjamin Schenk, who met at Dartmouth, had a pared-down guest list and ditched the reception dance floor in favor of contests and talent shows.
content: By now, 2020 wedding guests have read the boilerplate. “In light of Covid-19, we want to let you know your health and safety are our top priority,” banners at the top of wedding websites say. This is often followed by this year’s version of the big reveal: whether the wedding is on or off.
source.name: The New York Times

title: After Nagorno-Karabakh War, Trauma, Tragedy and Devastation
description: For Armenians uprooted from their homes, and for Azerbaijanis returning to uninhabitable towns, “It’s going to be very hard to forgive.”
content: FIZULI, Azerbaijan — Crossing into territory that Azerbaijan recently recaptured from Armenia is a journey into a devastated wasteland reminiscent of a World War I battlefield. The road passes miles of abandoned trenches and bunkers, and village after village of ruins, the white stones of homesteads scattered, every movable item — roofs, doors, window frames — picked clean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Krysten Chambrot
title: NYT Cooking’s 20 Most Popular Recipes of 2020
description: Caramelized shallot pasta, the perfect chocolate chip cookies, sour cream and onion chicken: These are the recipes that kept readers coming back for more.
content: The year 2020 saw a lot of unexpected food trends: the rise of the bean, so many pastas and readers flocking to home cooking. These are our top 20 recipes by traffic, the recipes that readers came back to time and time again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi
title: Argentina Moves Toward Legal Abortion Amid Push for Women’s Rights
description: Argentina’s President Alberto Fernández has made the rights of women and of gay and transgender people central to his government, even through a recession and a pandemic.
content: BUENOS AIRES — Argentine lawmakers took a major step on Friday toward legalizing abortion and fulfilling a promise of President Alberto Fernández, who has made women’s rights a central tenet of his government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennie Erin Smith
title: In Life, She Defied Alzheimer’s. In Death, Her Brain May Show How.
description: A woman in Colombia with a rare genetic mutation recently made the ultimate donation to science.
content: MEDELLÍN, Colombia — Aliria Rosa Piedrahita de Villegas carried a rare genetic mutation that had all but guaranteed she would develop Alzheimer’s disease in her 40s. But only at age 72 did she experience the first symptoms of it. Her dementia was not terribly advanced when she died from cancer on Nov. 10, a month shy of her 78th birthday, in her daughter’s home on a hillside that overlooks the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paige Darrah
title: How John Foley, Peloton Co-Founder, Spends His Sundays
description: A year ago Peloton was the butt of a holiday joke. Not anymore.
content: John Foley, the chief executive of Peloton, seems a bit uncomfortable with sporting a company logo as a fashion choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Reporting on Indigenous Australia
description: The more difficult the access to a story, the more often it is worth doing.
content: When I first heard about Australia’s “bush courts,” I knew they were something I wanted to report on. Makeshift courtrooms, fly-in legal services, and Australians processed through that system who neither understood English nor how the courts worked. The details shocked me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Progressive Groups Urge Biden to Move Quickly on Diverse Slate of Judges
description: The president-elect faces pressure to install a diverse group of progressives in the courts, but the prospect of a Republican-controlled Senate looms as an obstacle.
content: WASHINGTON — Hours after Joseph R. Biden Jr. was projected as the winner of the presidential election last month, Russ Feingold, the former Democratic senator who now leads the progressive American Constitution Society, delivered the names of scores of carefully screened candidates for federal judicial posts to top Biden transition officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: For Cameron Kinley and Navy, the Army Game Can Give 2020 a Highlight
description: The rivalry is being played at West Point, the first time the game has not been at a neutral site in 77 years.
content: Cameron Kinley, one of the captains of the Navy football team, read the text on his phone in late October and refused to believe it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Falsehoods and Threats
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: President Trump’s attempts to overturn the election result are very unlikely to succeed. For that reason, the effort can sometimes seem like a publicity stunt — an effort by Trump to raise money and burnish his image with his supporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Melena Ryzik
title: FKA twigs Sues Shia LaBeouf, Citing ‘Relentless’ Abusive Relationship
description: The lawsuit, filed in Los Angeles by the musician, accuses the actor of sexual battery, assault and infliction of emotional distress.
content: Just after Valentine’s Day in 2019, the musician FKA twigs was in a car speeding toward Los Angeles. At the wheel was her boyfriend, the actor Shia LaBeouf. He was driving recklessly, she said in a lawsuit filed on Friday, removing his seatbelt and threatening to crash unless she professed her love for him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate Sends Military Bill to Trump’s Desk, Spurning His Veto Threat
description: The move raised the prospect of a legislative showdown in the president’s final weeks in office on the bill that authorizes pay for the troops.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate overwhelmingly passed a sweeping military policy bill on Friday that would require that Confederate names be stripped from American military bases, clearing the measure for enactment and sending it to President Trump’s desk in defiance of his threats of a veto.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: German Cultural Leaders Warn Against Ban on Israel Sanctions Movement
description: Signatories of an open letter say a parliamentary resolution declaring the campaign anti-Semitic has led to self-censorship and is stifling artistic expression.
content: BERLIN —  For months, the leaders of dozens of Germany’s most prominent cultural institutions met in secret, swapping stories of self-censorship, of hours spent worrying about the social media histories of artists or scholars they wanted to invite to their programs, and fears for their futures, if they slipped up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samantha Drake
title: How to Save Phallic Flowers From Being Inbred to Extinction
description: To preserve corpse flowers and other rare plants, botanic gardens are borrowing studbooks, an approach used by zoos and horse breeders.
content: To save endangered plant species, horticulturalists are using a tactic they’ve borrowed from horse breeders and zookeepers, building breeding registries or “studbooks” to avoid inbreeding. Naturally, they’re starting with a plant with a Latin name that means “large misshapen penis.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Opam
title: The Biggest Casting News From Disney’s Investor Day
description: “Black Panther 2” will not recast King T’Challa. Harrison Ford is picking up the hat and whip again. And “Star Wars” recruited Rosario Dawson for her own show.
content: In unveiling a huge raft of content coming to theaters and its streaming service at a four-hour investor presentation on Thursday, Disney announced major cast news for many of its highest profile properties, including Pixar, Marvel and “Star Wars.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Magic Shows and Inner Beauty
description: How André Leon Talley, Sofia Carson and Stuart Weitzman are giving back during the pandemic.
content: With the New York charity circuit on hiatus, here is how some philanthropists and society figures are spending their time and resources during the coronavirus crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Guide to Georgia’s Senate Runoffs
description: Georgia flipped blue for Joe Biden. Now two costly battles there will decide control of the Senate.
content: In three weeks, an election will take place that could be as important as the presidential vote in determining the course of the next four years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘Driving While Black’ and ‘Life Isn’t Everything’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: THE DOLPHIN LETTERS, 1970-1979: Elizabeth Hardwick, Robert Lowell, and Their Circle, edited by Saskia Hamilton. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 560 pp., $22.) “The Dolphin” is the book of poems in which Lowell lifted, and altered, lines from Hardwick’s anguished letters to him after he left her for the British novelist Carolyn Blackwood. “Their circle” includes the likes of Elizabeth Bishop, Adrienne Rich and Mary McCarthy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thom Dunn
title: How Not to Burn Down Your House With a Space Heater
description: The tiny radiators, while useful, cause thousands of fires and hundreds of deaths each year. Here are some tips to stay safe while you stay warm.
content: One day last winter, I was down in my unfinished basement working on some music, and my fingers were too cold to play the guitar. So I grabbed a space heater that I was long-term testing for Wirecutter, placed it on the wooden workbench where my audio workstation was set up, and plugged it into the nearest power strip — the one my Marshall amplifier was also plugged into.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Gabrielle Hamilton’s marvelous new recipe for white borscht may just become one of your favorites.
content: Good morning. Gabrielle Hamilton is in The Times this week with a marvelous new recipe for white borscht (above) that pays homage to the $2.50 bowls of soup she used to eat in her early days in the East Village, when Polish and Ukrainian diners were thick on the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Quammen
title: The Virus, the Bats and Us
description: They probably spread the virus that’s killing humans. We almost certainly spread the fungus that’s killing them.
content: The order of animals known as Chiroptera, the bats, enjoys a mixed reputation among humans. I’m putting this politely: They have been calumniated and abused for centuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder, Lauryn Higgins and Benjamin Guggenheim
title: Secrecy surrounds the reporting of Covid-19 cases in college athletics.
description: More than 6,600 college athletes, coaches and staff members have tested positive for the coronavirus this year, a dispiriting measure of the pathogen’s reach across the United States and its spread among some of the country’s most closely monitored people.
content: More than 6,600 college athletes, coaches and staff members have tested positive for the coronavirus this year, a dispiriting measure of the pathogen’s reach across the United States and its spread among some of the country’s most closely monitored people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: California Travel Restrictions: What You Need to Know
description: Restrictions in the state are complicated and changing quickly, leading to confusion about travel rules.
content: California has introduced new restrictions on travel and other aspects of daily life to combat the state’s surge in coronavirus cases and prevent hospitals from being overwhelmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Trump slams the F.D.A. ahead of expected vaccine authorization.
description: President Trump lashed out anew at the Food and Drug Administration in a Friday morning tweet, attacking the agency’s commissioner, Dr. Stephen M. Hahn, by name for not approving a Covid-19 vaccine faster.
content: President Trump lashed out anew at the Food and Drug Administration in a Friday morning tweet, attacking the agency’s commissioner, Dr. Stephen M. Hahn, by name for not approving a Covid-19 vaccine faster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Black Ballerina, Playing a Swan, Says She Was Told to Color Her Skin
description: The dancer with the Staatsballett Berlin says being directed to use white makeup to perform in “Swan Lake” was one of the racially insensitive incidents she has faced.
content: Chloé Lopes Gomes had done her hair and makeup and fixed the feathered swan headdress in place before the rehearsal in February. Then, she later recounted, she repeatedly dipped a wet sponge into a pot of white pancake makeup, applying it carefully to her face, neck and upper body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Lil Wayne Pleads Guilty to Federal Gun Charge
description: The rapper will be sentenced in January, and faces up to 10 years in prison.
content: The rapper Lil Wayne pleaded guilty on Friday to having illegally carried a gold-plated .45-caliber Glock handgun and ammunition as a felon while traveling on a private jet last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Chris Cameron and Andy Newman
title: As two-thirds of House Republicans support the Texas election suit, a Democrat called them ‘traitors.’
description: With nearly two-thirds of House Republicans supporting Texas’s lawsuit seeking to overturn the election in the U.S. Supreme Court, a Democratic House member on Friday called the Republicans “traitors” and urged the House’s Democratic leadership not to seat the Republicans when the 117th Congress convenes in January.
content: With nearly two-thirds of House Republicans supporting Texas’s lawsuit seeking to overturn the election in the U.S. Supreme Court, a Democratic House member on Friday called the Republicans “traitors” and urged the House’s Democratic leadership not to seat the Republicans when the 117th Congress convenes in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik and Juliana Kim
title: 6 Injured When Driver Rams Into Protest Against ICE in Manhattan
description: A black car hit several people marching in Manhattan in support of immigrant detainees on a hunger strike.
content: About a half-dozen people stand around a black BMW sedan in a Manhattan street. At least one slaps a hand onto one of the car’s windows as the vehicle edges through the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Gopnik
title: The Mixed Message of Earth-Friendly Design
description: “Broken Nature” at MoMA offers up a trove of ‘restorative’ projects. Does buying more elegant objects help heal the planet?
content: The design store of the Museum of Modern Art sits on the south side of 53rd Street in New York, just up from the ritzy shops of Fifth Avenue. It is dedicated to adding more fabulous objects to the vast supply of goods our households — and planet — are bursting with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: The Women Faced Off to Play Soccer. One Team Lost Because of Hair Dye.
description: A Chinese university team argued that an opposing player’s hair was not “black enough,” according to the rules, and her team forfeited the match.
content: Forget skill, training or even luck. If you’re a female soccer player in China, sometimes victory or defeat comes down to the color of your hair, as one university team recently found out the hard way.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Jobless Claims Jump, Casting New Shadow Over Economy
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 11, 2020.
content: “Mutual aid between unemployed people can only go so far. People are donating $5 to each other’s GoFundMes in a perpetual circle just trying to survive.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Champions League’s New Twist: Injury Roulette
description: With muscle injuries rising and an unforgiving, pandemic-compressed schedule looming, Europe might not crown its best team this season, but the one that’s still standing.
content: The procession was nearly over. Ninety-five of the 96 games that constitute the group phase of the Champions League, six weeks of phony war that largely serve to check boxes, cross Ts and dot Is, were complete. Most of the heavyweights had long since advanced to the knockout rounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tricia Tisak
title: 18 Things That Happened for the First Time in 2020
description: Surprising and serious events and trends noted for the first time ever this year.
content: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: It’s ‘Debt Parking’: When Fake Debts End Up on Your Credit Report
description: The F.T.C. recently took its first legal action to stop the fraud. Consumers may not know the debts are on their reports until they apply for a loan.
content: Consider this unnerving situation: You apply for a loan only to learn that your credit report is marred by a delinquent debt — one that you have already paid or maybe don’t recognize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: An F.D.A. panel gives the Pfizer vaccine the green light.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Congress, Paralyzed on a Stimulus Deal, Gives Itself Another Week to Strike One
description: The Senate cleared a weeklong stopgap spending bill to buy time for an elusive pandemic aid bill, but negotiators remained short of an agreement.
content: WASHINGTON — After months of fruitless haggling and a frenzied few days of revived talks, Congress missed yet another deadline on Friday to deliver an economic stimulus package to help struggling Americans weather the pandemic, instead agreeing to extend government funding for an additional week as leaders continued to search for a deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The ‘Trump Won’ Farce Isn’t Funny Anymore
description: Republicans are now seriously arguing that elections are legitimate only when their side wins.
content: To tell a joke to a crowd is to learn a little something about the people who laugh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Dana Rubinstein
title: Midtown Is Reeling. Should Its Offices Become Apartments?
description: The pandemic has created a crisis in New York City’s commercial real estate industry. Some leaders think it’s time to reimagine the city’s business districts.
content: The pandemic is pummeling New York City’s commercial real estate industry, one of its main economic engines, threatening the future of the nation’s largest business districts as well as the city’s finances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Is Andrew Yang Running for Mayor? All Signs Point to Yes
description: The former Democratic presidential candidate is meeting with New York City power brokers and telling them he intends to enter the race to succeed Bill de Blasio.
content: Andrew Yang, the former tech executive who gained a national following as a Democratic presidential candidate, has been privately telling New York City leaders that he intends to run for mayor next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rejects Texas Suit Seeking to Subvert Election
description: The suit, filed directly in the Supreme Court, sought to bar Georgia, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin from casting their electoral votes for Joseph R. Biden Jr.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday rejected a lawsuit by Texas that had asked the court to throw out the election results in four battleground states that President Trump lost in November, ending any prospect that a brazen attempt to use the courts to reverse his defeat at the polls would succeed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gal Beckerman and Noor Qasim
title: What’s Fauci Reading? We Take Another Look at Celebrity Bookshelves
description: This year is finally coming to an end, so here is one last peek at the books behind Chris Rock, Jeff Bezos, Jemele Hill, Julia Louis-Dreyfus and more.
content: As 2020 winds down and we look back at our pandemic year, it’s possible, through the murk of loneliness and illness, to see the few bright spots that existed for people who love books. We had the chance to peruse a lot of strangers’ bookshelves — nearly every time we turned on the television or began a video call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Same-Sex Kisses Under the Mistletoe: Holiday Movies Rethink a Formula
description: In a conservative genre that has mainly told straight stories, six new films, including titles on Hallmark and Lifetime, center on gay or lesbian characters.
content: Will the adorable couple adopt a baby in time to celebrate Christmas with Mom and Dad and the neighborhood kids? Sounds like a delightful holiday TV movie. But this is disruptive 2020, so here’s the thing: the couple are Brandon and Jake and the channel is Hallmark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Tommy Lister, Actor Who Menaced as Deebo in ‘Friday,’ Is Dead at 62
description: The actor was found dead in his California home on Thursday after friends and business associates could not reach him, the authorities said.
content: Tommy Lister, a 6-foot-5-inch actor nicknamed Tiny who played the hulking neighborhood bully Deebo in the “Friday” films, has died at his home in Marina del Rey, Calif. He was 62.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard A. Friedman
title: We Must Do More to Stop Dangerous Doctors in a Pandemic
description: Some have crossed the line from free speech to medical practice — or something akin to malpractice.
content: It’s bad enough when our political leaders promote quack theories about coronavirus and its treatment; but what do we do about the doctors who enable them and use their medical authority to promote pseudoscience?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A panel of experts at the F.D.A. formally recommended that the agency authorize Pfizer’s vaccine.
content: A panel of experts at the Food and Drug Administration formally recommended today that the agency authorize the vaccine. The agency is likely to do so within days, clearing the way for health care workers and nursing home residents to begin receiving it early next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Investigation of His Son Is Likely to Hang Over Biden as He Takes Office
description: Unless the Trump Justice Department clears Hunter Biden, the new president will confront the prospect of his own administration handling an inquiry that could expose his son to criminal prosecution.
content: WASHINGTON — The newly disclosed federal tax investigation into his son will test President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s stated commitment to independent law enforcement while leaving him in a no-win situation that could prove distracting at best and politically and legally perilous at worst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Johnson
title: Protesters Erect Barricades in Portland to Save a Black Family’s House
description: The family lost its home of 60 years to foreclosure after taking out mortgages to pay legal fees. Some advocates say gentrification and skyrocketing prices are driving Black families out of the city.
content: A standoff between the police and protesters over a mixed-race family’s eviction in Portland, Ore., is stirring up old ghosts of segregation and redlining from the 20th century, when Black families moved in for jobs and found that there were only certain places they could live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Othella Dallas, Keeper of Katherine Dunham’s Flame, Dies at 95
description: Ms. Dallas taught the Afro-Caribbean-influenced Dunham dance technique in Europe well into her 90s. She also had a career as a blues, jazz and R&B singer.
content: Othella Dallas, who was one of the last surviving early members of the Katherine Dunham Dance Company, the nation’s first self-supporting Black modern dance troupe, and taught the Afro-Caribbean-influenced Dunham technique in Europe well into her 90s, died on Nov. 28 at a nursing home in Binningen, Switzerland. She was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Wander Darkly’ Review: After Death, a Fractured Life
description: In this drama, Sienna Miller plays a woman who gets to witness her own funeral after a car crash.
content: Surviving a car crash, even a minor one, is a singular experience. In “Wander Darkly,” a film written and directed by Tara Miele, Adrienne (Sienna Miller) has an extra-singular experience — she dies in her auto accident, but lives on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by Will Dudding, Anna Schaverien and Jessica Anderson
title: News Quiz: Facebook, Universal, Chuck Yeager
description: Did you follow the headlines this week?
content: Did you follow the headlines this week?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Goldfarb
title: 4 Ways to Feel Less Lonely Over the Holidays
description: As the weather turns colder and states implement new lockdown restrictions, try one of these ideas to connect with others.
content: As the weather turns colder and states implement new lockdown restrictions, try one of these ideas to connect with others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
description: President Trump and his team are still providing a plethora of fodder for late-night hosts. Here are some highlights.
content: President Trump and his team are still providing a plethora of fodder for late-night hosts. Here are some highlights.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: The State of the Virus This Week
description: A look at this week’s news from the team tracking the coronavirus.
content: A look at this week’s news from the team tracking the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Jean So and Gus Wezerek
title: Why Is Publishing So White?
description: New data shows the extent of the book industry’s race problem.
content: New data shows the extent of the book industry’s race problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yuliya Parshina-Kottas, Amy Schoenfeld Walker and Jeremy White
title: How the Vaccine Will Get From the Lab to You
description: With a promise to deliver millions of doses in the coming weeks, the government and its massive logistical effort to get the vaccine out across the United States are about to be tested.
content: With a promise to deliver millions of doses in the coming weeks, the government and its massive logistical effort to get the vaccine out across the United States are about to be tested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Ivory, Mitch Smith, Jasmine C. Lee, Jordan Allen, Alex Lemonides, Barbara Harvey, Alex Leeds Matthews, Cierra S. Queen, Natasha Rodriguez and John Yoon
title: How Many Vaccine Doses Will Your State Get?
description: The New York Times surveyed all 50 states for their estimates of coronavirus vaccine doses they expect to receive before the end of the year.
content: The New York Times surveyed all 50 states for their estimates of coronavirus vaccine doses they expect to receive before the end of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jillian Rayfield
title: The Weekender
description: The best actors of 2020. Barack Obama on his best-selling memoir. The rise and fall of a celebrity pastor. An attempt at counting Australia’s koalas. And more.
content: The best actors of 2020. Barack Obama on his best-selling memoir. The rise and fall of a celebrity pastor. An attempt at counting Australia’s koalas. And more.

title: Our Critics’ Top Picks of 2020
description: The great film, TV, performance, art and books that emerged in a not-so-great year.
content: The great film, TV, performance, art and books that emerged in a not-so-great year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Australia Scraps Coronavirus Vaccine
description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia on Friday canceled a large order of a developed coronavirus vaccine after not having the approval from the Therapeutic Goods Administration, the country’s drug regulator.
content: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia on Friday canceled a large order of a developed coronavirus vaccine after not having the approval from the Therapeutic Goods Administration, the country’s drug regulator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Police Footage Shows Raid on Florida Data Scientist
description: Body camera footage released by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement shows a search this week at the home of Rebekah D. Jones, a data scientist who had managed the state’s coronavirus dashboard.
content: Body camera footage released by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement shows a search this week at the home of Rebekah D. Jones, a data scientist who had managed the state’s coronavirus dashboard.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘A Bit of Light on the Horizon’
description: What it felt like to witness some of the first coronavirus vaccinations in Britain. Plus, what we’re listening to.
